title: Yves Klein’s ‘Barbara (ANT) 113’ Could Fetch $12M-$18M
text:
Text size

Christie’s will offer a massive, deep blue, monochromatic abstract from Yves Klein’s Anthropométries series at its Nov. 13 evening sale of post-war and contemporary art in New York.

Barbara (ANT 113), 1960—an example from a famous series by Klein, in which the French artist orchestrated the movements of naked female models covered in paint on paper and canvas—is estimated to sell for between $12 million and $18 million.

At nearly 79 inches by 57 inches, ANT 113 is one of the larger works in Anthropométries. But Christie’s sold an even more monumental example, Anthropométrie "Le Buffle" (ANT 93), 1960-61, which is about 70 inches by 110 inches, in May 2010.

Le Buffle sold for $12.4 million, with fees, the highest known price for a work from the series at auction. At the current estimate, Barbara (ANT 113) could possibly achieve a record.

Barbara (ANT 113) “is brimming with dynamism and intensity,” Alex Rotter, Christie’s chairman of post-war and contemporary art, said in a news release Monday.

Both Anthropométrie works feature the artist’s signature International Klein Blue (IKB) pigment, a deep yet bright blue. Klein orchestrated the models’ movements across the canvases, inaugurating the series with a live performance. Christie’s says ANT 113 is one of a subset “in which the body appears to take flight.” Other works in this subset include Princess Helena, which is at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and ANT 130 in Museum Ludwig, Cologne, Germany.

The painting is being offered from an anonymous private collection. The seller is designating a portion of the sale proceeds go toward a Switzerland-based international nonprofit, the Water Academy for Sustainable and Responsible Development Foundation, which is creating and advancing scientific and cultural information concerning the access and management of global water resources, Christie’s said in the release.
description: Some proceeds from the sale of the monochromatic work from the artist’s Anthropométries series will fund an international water charity
